courseDescription: The course analyzes the origins of regional planning agencies, current organizational structures, financing and functional activities.  The focus is on the application of the systems approach to metropolitan planning issues.  This latter objective is achieved through participation in exercises dealing with economics, transportation and land-use allocation modeling.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of regional planning agencies origins

courseTitle: Administrative Theory I: The Context of Public Administration
courseDescription: Introduction to the profession of public administration; the evolution and development of the field, the role of organizations in contemporary American government, and the roles of politics and administration.  The course also provides an introduction to the necessary skills for successful graduate study.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public administration evolution and development
Comprehension of the role of organizations in American government
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and interact in the context of public administration
Effective communication in the field of public administration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the roles of politics and administration
Critical evaluation of public administration theories
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of organizational structure in government
Leadership within the context of public administration

courseTitle: Administrative Theory II: The Process of Public Administration
courseDescription: Introduction to management in the public sector.  Topics include: organizing public agencies, managing people and work groups, introduction to organizational systems (human resources, budget, and information systems), and effective leadership and decision-making processes.

This course deals with some of the many complex, intractable, or "wicked" problems that public and non-profit sector professionals will struggle with during the course of their careers. In the context of public administration, a wicked problem is a set of conditions and circumstances that seems to defy resolution or even amelioration because of the incredibly complex nature of the situation.
Required of all students without previous experience in government service.  Supervised work experience in a public agency. A written report will be required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building rapport with colleagues and supervisors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and understanding problems in a public agency setting
Critical evaluation of public agency procedures

courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to examine the institutions, principles, and techniques of national, state, and local budgeting processes and financial administration.  The course explores the allocation as well as the re-distributive role of government and the market.  While applying information technology, students will analyze the practices and fundamental concepts of government budgeting, financial management, and public finance, with an emphasis on revenue, expenditure, capital budgeting and debt structures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of information technology in financial administration
Understanding of capital budgeting and debt structures
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and interpretation of financial management concepts
Analysis of the re-distributive role of government and the market
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of national, state, and local budgeting processes
Allocation and management of government resources

courseDescription: Topics vary each semester.
Specifically planned readings for the graduate student who wishes to pursue special interests outside the scope of formal studies. Supervised on an individual basis.
Supervised research on a specific program. A written report will be required.

An approved research project, written under the supervision of a faculty committee, in which the student demonstrates the capacity to design and complete independent scholarly investigation.  The completed project must be approved by the thesis committee.

Exploration of key theories and approaches to public policy. This course covers all phases of the policy process, from formulation to evaluation, with particular focus upon the substance, political dynamics, and evolution of public policy.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of policy issues

courseDescription: Examination of various methodologies for designing and conducting program evaluation and research. Experimental, quasi-experimental and nonexperimental procedures will be covered. (Cross listed with PPCM 704)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of different methodologies

courseDescription: This course examines the theory and practice of urban and regional economic development.  The tools, institutions, and analytical techniques of urban and regional economic development are examined in light of relevant public policy issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of economic development tools and institutions
Application of analytical techniques in urban and regional economics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on public policy issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing urban and regional economic issues
Applying economic theories to real-world issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing economic development strategies

courseDescription: Analysis of the range of administrative tools and strategies for the delivery of government services. Emphasizes new administrative alternatives under conditions of constant change.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of government service delivery systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team coordination in service delivery
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and implementation of administrative strategies
Problem-solving under conditions of constant change

courseDescription: Explores policy and regulatory issues of emergency management; intergovernmental responsibilities and relationships among local, state and federal agencies in an "all hazards" approach to preparing and responding to manmade and natural disasters. Examines challenges faced by local, state, and federal managers during a large scale disaster.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of emergency policy and regulatory issues
Knowledge of intergovernmental responsibilities in disaster management
Familiarity with 'all hazards' approach in preparing and responding to disasters
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with local, state, and federal agencies
Coordination among multiple stakeholders in emergency situations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and responding to large scale disaster challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing responsibilities and relationships in emergency situations
Leading and coordinating disaster response efforts

courseDescription: This course introduces students to fundraising principles of nonprofit organizations with an emphasis on different types of philanthropy, fundraising theories and practices, and motivations of givers. They will develop skills in creative problem solving for fundraising practice while learning to analyze and evaluate the fundraising process and methods. Additionally, students will develop the ability to synthesize and integrate current information and emerging ideas into a fundraising strategy and to think critically and analytically about a variety of fundraising perspectives.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of current information and emerging ideas into fundraising practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking about various fundraising perspectives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and synthesizing information for fundraising strategy

courseDescription: An in-depth analysis of the forces behind the privatization movement. Examines the context of privatization, the theoretical and empirical arguments on both sides of the debate, and the different forms of privatization practiced in the U.S. The course draws on a wide range of disciplines in a quest for an understanding of the privatization phenomenon-political science, public administration, public policy, sociology, economics, management, and others. (Cross listed with PPCM 714)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative evaluation of different privatization forms

courseTitle: Management and Governance of Nonprofit Organizations
courseDescription: Successful nonprofit organizations require substantial capability in key areas of management such as developing a strong board of directors, recruiting and motivating talented staff and volunteers, creating a strategic plan, and wisely managing fiscal and human resources. The course is built around understanding nonprofit governance structures, relationships, and responsibilities as well as unique management issues associated with them. This course addresses these topics from theoretical and practitioner perspectives.

This course offers a broad introduction to the study and practice of the nonprofit sector. The course explores the history, scope, and significance of the nonprofit sector as it relates to philanthropy, voluntary action, civil society, and civic engagement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching historical trends in the nonprofit sector
Understanding the digital landscape of philanthropy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the scope and significance of nonprofit organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying principles of nonprofit leadership

courseDescription: This course provides students with the knowledge to become effective financial managers by giving them practical applications of theory and skill-building in fiscal and accounting processes of nonprofit organizations.

Examines the actions that must be taken following the award of a contract, including assurance of required outcomes, assurance of compliance, proper contract launch, proper contract close-out, and documentation and carrying forward lessons learned. Connections to steps that must be taken in the other two phases of the procurement process are noted. (Course is cross listed with PPCM 718)
Technical and Digital Skills: Documentation and carrying forward lessons learned
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiation of contract terms and conditions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading contract launch and close-out procedures

courseDescription: Examines leadership through theoretical and practice-based frameworks. Offers analytical and intellectual examination and reflection on core issues in the practice of leadership. These objectives will be achieved through open discussion, honest self-assessment, experiential exercises, and observation of real-life leadership practice. (Cross listed with PPCM 719)
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding theoretical and practice-based leadership frameworks

courseDescription: Examines the basic framework of the public personnel system beginning with the legal requirements imposed by federal and state laws and regulations.  General considerations of policy and procedures development, the organization of the public personnel system, the adoption of the personnel ordinance, the determination of various levels of employee status and the coverage of the personnel system are included.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation and application of federal and state laws
Effective communication within a public personnel system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and adjustment of personnel system coverage
Problem-solving in policy and procedure development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership within a public personnel system
Organizational understanding of public personnel systems

courseDescription: Lecture, 3 hours; 3 credits.  This course focuses on surface transportation policy and planning, and highways and roads in particular.  Topics include local, state and federal policies, public involvement in transportation planning, transportation and highway finance, privatization and public-private partnerships, critical issues and policy questions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of surface transportation policy and planning
Familiarity with local, state and federal policies
Understanding of transportation and highway finance
Understanding of privatization and public-private partnerships
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in transportation and highway finance
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading public involvement in transportation planning

courseDescription: This course reviews the theory and application of ethics in the public sector, identifying public values and how they apply in the administration of government.  It reviews sources of values employed in public sector decision-making, and reviews how values in public administration are managed and applied.  Systems of professional ethics are reviewed in the context of public professions.  Case studies and best practices are examined to help the student understand the application of administrative ethics in public management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of professional ethics systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Navigating ethical dilemmas in public discourse
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of ethical case studies in public administration
Critical evaluation of sources of values
Understanding and applying best practices in administrative ethics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing public values in the administration of government

courseDescription: Analysis of human services involving direct client/agency interaction.  Problems of discretion and control are examined as alternative service delivery strategies which can deal with these problems.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients and agencies

courseDescription: This course studies the interdependencies and interactions among three broad entities - business, government, and society - in the delivery of public services, paying special attention to their implications for public policy.

This course provides an overview of procurement and contract management as a core function in public sector organizations. The course introduces the student to how properly-aligned, best practice acquisitions can support public entities' strategic goals. Challenges and opportunities for all stakeholders are addressed. Special attention is given to ongoing changes in public procurement. (Cross listed with PPCM 726)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of procurement and contract management
Adaptability to ongoing changes in public procurement
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to address challenges and opportunities for all stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and resolution of procurement challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Alignment of acquisitions with strategic goals

courseDescription: Course covers each phase of the public procurement project cycle, with an emphasis on tools and techniques to manage a public procurement project. (Cross listed with PPCM 727)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public procurement project cycle
Proficiency in project management tools and techniques
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration in a public procurement setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to identify and resolve procurement-related issues
Analytical skills to evaluate project performance and make improvements
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in a public procurement environment
Ability to manage and lead a procurement project

courseTitle: Public Sector Contract Planning and Formation
courseDescription: This course provides insight into why and how public sector contracts should be planned and formed properly. A strong emphasis is placed on the strategic role that procurement can play in public sector organizations and how procurement planning and source selection, in particular, fit into that role. (Cross listed with PPCM 728.)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in public sector organizations

courseTitle: Public Sector Procurement Law and Ethics
courseDescription: This course surveys the laws and ethics applicable to public sector procurement and contract management. A theoretical and problem-based, interdisciplinary approach is used to address the major legal and ethical issues that arise when public sector organizations plan, form, and administer contracts. Attention is given to the role of professionalization in socializing appropriate ethics. (Cross listed with PPCM 731)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of ethical issues in public procurement
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of legal and ethical issues

courseDescription: The course provides conceptual and practical skills in negotiations. It examines the underlying cultural, legal, and organizational issues and problems that affect managing human resources in the workplace. (Cross listed with PPCM 734)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Addressing cultural, legal and organizational issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem diagnosis in human resource management

courseTitle: History of Race and Government Institutions
courseDescription: U.S. history is examined through a racial lens in the context of public administration: policies, laws, and court actions at the federal, state, and local levels. Three historical eras will be examined from colonial days to the present: Pre-Civil War Slavery, Jim Crow Segregation, and Mass Incarceration/ Colorblind Racism. Two transitional periods will also be covered: Post-Civil War Reconstruction and the Civil Rights Movement.

courseTitle: Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion: A Public Administration and Public Policy Perspective
courseDescription: Across every economic and social indicator, there are disparities that are based on race, gender, and culture. In the U.S., some of the disparities have been created by explicit and intentional discrimination that was incorporated into the U.S. Constitution and various federal, state, and local laws. Other disparities grew out of unconscious or unintended impacts of federal, state, and local laws, policies, and practices. This course will examine these issues within the context of public administration, developing an awareness of inequities and the skills to dismantle discriminatory policies and practices.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and mitigation of unintended policy impacts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for equity and inclusion

courseDescription: This course focuses on the growing challenges and opportunities created by our interconnected world and the knowledge and abilities necessary to lead through situations in which there are misunderstandings or conflicts rooted in differences. The course explores the structure and dynamics of all forms of diversity in public, non-profit, and governmental organizations, the resulting implications for organizational health, and the critical role of cultural-competent leadership.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and communicating with diverse groups
Resolving conflicts rooted in cultural differences
Effective communication in public, non-profit, and governmental organizations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing dynamics of diversity in different organizational structures
Identifying potential misunderstandings or conflicts caused by cultural differences
Developing strategies to handle cultural differences and conflicts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading through situations with cultural misunderstandings or conflicts
Promoting organizational health in diverse settings
Understanding the implications of diversity on organizational health

courseDescription: This course examines the importance of social, economic, cultural, religious, and civic organizations in building or restoring communities. The course focuses on the revitalization, restoration, or upgrading of communities, cities, and localities or neighborhoods within or adjacent to cities, by the residents themselves. Viewed through the lens of social capital theory, the course further explores examples of short- and long-term change accomplished by community members on their own, within organizations, or in partnership with government officials.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of social, economic, cultural, and religious factors in community building

courseTitle: Managing Development and Change in Organizations
courseDescription: Examination of the theory and practice of organization development.  Participants will take the role of change agent and public manager and apply a range of organization development techniques to public agency situations while giving attention to the particular cultural, political, legal and organizational characteristics of public organizations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Role-playing as a change agent and public manager
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding legal and political aspects of organizations

courseDescription: Presents an integrated approach to the field of public administration, and examines the political, administrative, and social implications of administrative choices.  The emphasis of the course will be a case approach to public administration and public management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of political, administrative, and social implications

courseDescription: This course focuses on performance-based management approaches in public and non-profit settings. It addresses the performance measurement and management process, the identification of appropriate performance measures, and the implementation of a performance measurement system, as well as managing for performance.

An introduction to statistics for students in Public Administration and related fields. Emphasis is placed on the quantitative analysis of demographics and factors affecting public administrators in the field.

This course examines various methods for designing and conducting research, collecting and organizing data, and disseminating results.  Information technology and applications to practical management problems and public research topics are emphasized.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of information technology in research
Application of research methods to practical management problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of research methods to public research topics

courseDescription: An examination of the fundamental concepts of collaborative governance in the field of public administration and public policy. Emphasis is placed on the government and/or nonprofit management and process of collaborative problem solving and policy implementation in cross-sector and intra-sector environments.

Examination of public sector financial principles, practices, and processes. A public manager's perspective of the decision making and practices of managing public funds. Introduction to governmental accounting practices. Emphasis on analyzing financial statements for decision making. Extensive use of Excel spreadsheet. Exploration of public financial management research and the link between public financial management practices and public fiscal and monetary policies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public fiscal and monetary policies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making in public fund management
Analysis of financial statements for decision making
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Practices and processes of managing public funds

courseDescription: This course provides students with the professional knowledge, skills, and abilities to engage successfully with local governments from the following perspectives: as a generalist public administrator, as a local government specialist, and as a citizen, non-profit leader, or businessperson. In addition, this course provides students with the theoretical and policy context within which local governments operate. Students will master that knowledge by researching how local governments use those concepts in every day administration.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Engagement with citizens, non-profit leaders, and businesspeople

courseDescription: Analysis of relationships among federal, state, and local governmental units in the delivery of governmental programs. Focus on intergovernmental issues in urban metropolitan regions. (Cross listed with PPCM 781)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of federal, state, and local government structure
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within urban metropolitan regions

courseTitle: Social Marketing in the Public Sector
courseDescription: The course is an examination of the principles, practices, and use of Social Marketing - the use of techniques to influence a target audience to voluntarily accept, reject, modify, or abandon a behavior for the benefit of individuals, groups, or society as a whole - in the public sector. In addition, the course will familiarize students with current and potential uses of Social Marketing to accomplish public sector goals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to identify potential uses of Social Marketing in the public sector
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting behavior change for societal benefit
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of Social Marketing strategies
Modifying Social Marketing techniques to better achieve public sector goals
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing Social Marketing campaigns
Adapting Social Marketing practices to various public sector contexts

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the field, the academy, the School of Public Service faculty, and university resources; it also sets program expectations for students. Topics include: research process, developing a research agenda, critical analysis of literature, professional development, comprehensive exams process, and academic v. nonacademic careers.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Networking with faculty and other resources
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Career planning in academic and non-academic settings

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of theories of public policy. It provides a solid foundation for knowledge in this area. Students will be introduced to the leading theories, frameworks, and models that help describe and explain the policy process. The course examines the historical heritages of the policy sciences and the bases upon which public policy discussions take place at all stages of the policy process.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of policy models and frameworks
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical heritages of policy sciences

courseDescription: The course reviews the history of administrative theory and the broad topics of administrative theory. The course is intended to address the impact that organizational structure and political/social environment have on administration. This course will not cover every theory, model, or framework relevant to public administration. However, this course is intended to provide the doctoral student with the theoretical foundations of public administration and understanding of their historical context in the field.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and communicating within political/social environments
Engaging with historical context and its relevance
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of models and frameworks relevant to public administration
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the impact of political/social environments on administration

courseDescription: This course is a continuation of PADM 802 and is intended to provide a framework for doctoral students to develop their understanding of public and nonprofit management organizational practices in the American context. The course is not exclusively directed to any one level of government, but includes national, state, and local management and organizational behavior. The course provides material on the concepts and perspectives on managerial rationale, responsibilities, decision making, and approaches to administration.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public and nonprofit management organizational practices
Knowledge of national, state, and local management and organizational behavior
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making in public and nonprofit sectors

courseDescription: The course explores public administration from Neoliberalism and beyond to focus on the development of multi-sector administration, where multi-sector is defined as policy action across governments, nonprofit organizations, for-profit organizations, and/or grass-roots groups and individuals. The course is expected to cover the methods, challenges, and consequences of multi-sector administration. This course will also address the management and evaluation of multi-sector relationships. This is not an introduction to organizational structure or theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Neoliberalism impact on public administration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the challenges of multi-sector administration
Identifying and addressing potential issues in multi-sector collaborations

courseDescription: The course examines advanced research design and evaluation methods used in public administration and management research. Experimental, quasi-experimental, and non­experimental procedures in the context of urban settings will be emphasized. Includes usage of various statistical software.

This course explores the proper use, calculation, and interpretation of multivariate statistics as commonly found in the literature in public administration. The course will prepare students to choose the appropriate statistical tools, generate testable hypotheses, correctly apply the statistical tool, analyze the results, and present and interpret the results of those tests in a manner appropriate for public administration in the field.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting statistical results for public administration
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying statistical tools for public administration decision-making

courseDescription: This course examines the theory and practice of urban and regional economic development. The tools, institutions, and analytical techniques of urban and regional economic development are examined in light of relevant public policy issues.
Examination of various methodologies for designing and conducting public policy and program evaluation and research. Experimental, quasi-experimental and non-experimental procedures will be covered.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Translating complex methodologies into clear concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of research and evaluation data
Problem-solving in design and execution of evaluations

courseDescription: Analysis of the range of administrative tools and strategies for the delivery of government services. Emphasizes new administrative alternatives under conditions of constant change.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of administrative tools for government services
Evaluation of technological trends in administration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of administrative tools and strategies

courseDescription: Explores policy and regulatory issues of emergency management; intergovernmental responsibilities and relationships among local, state and federal agencies in an "all hazards" approach to preparing and responding to manmade and natural disasters. Examines challenges faced by local, state, and federal managers during a large scale disaster.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of intergovernmental responsibilities and relationships
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Coordination with local, state and federal agencies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing challenges in large scale disaster management
Developing solutions for manmade and natural disasters
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and preparation for potential emergencies

courseDescription: This course introduces students to fundraising principles of nonprofit organizations with an emphasis on different types of philanthropy, fundraising theories and practices, and motivations of givers. They will develop skills in creative problem solving for fundraising practice while learning to analyze and evaluate the fundraising process and methods. Additionally, students will develop the ability to synthesize and integrate current information and emerging ideas into a fundraising strategy and to think critically and analytically about a variety of fundraising perspectives.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of current information and emerging ideas
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and evaluating fundraising processes and methods
Critical and analytical thinking about various fundraising perspectives

courseDescription: An in-depth analysis of the forces behind the privatization movement. Examines the context of privatization, the theoretical and empirical arguments on both sides of the debate, and the different forms of privatization practiced in the U.S. The course draws on a wide range of disciplines in a quest for an understanding of the privatization phenomenon-political science, public administration, public policy, sociology, economics, management, and others.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of privatization forms and contexts

courseTitle: Management and Governance of Nonprofit Organizations
courseDescription: Successful nonprofit organizations require substantial capability in key areas of management such as developing a strong board of directors, recruiting and motivating talented staff and volunteers, creating a strategic plan, and wisely managing fiscal and human resources. The course is built around understanding nonprofit governance structures, relationships, and responsibilities as well as unique management issues associated with them. This course addresses these topics from theoretical and practitioner perspectives.

This course offers a broad introduction to the study and practice of the nonprofit sector. The course explores the history, scope, and significance of the nonprofit sector as it relates to philanthropy, voluntary action, civil society, and civic engagement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using digital platforms for civic engagement
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a nonprofit setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact and significance of nonprofit sector
Evaluating the scope of the nonprofit sector
Assessing trends and patterns in philanthropy and voluntary action

courseTitle: Nonprofit Financial Management and Fund Raising
courseDescription: Lecture 3 hours; 3 credits.  This course provides students with the knowledge to become effective financial managers by giving them practical applications of theory and skill-building in fiscal processes and fundraising of nonprofit organizations.

Examines leadership through theoretical and practice-based frameworks. Offers analytical and intellectual examination and reflection on core issues in the practice of leadership. These objectives will be achieved through open discussion, honest self-assessment, experiential exercises, and observation of real-life leadership practice.

Examines leadership through theoretical and practice-based frameworks. Offers analytical and intellectual examination and reflection on core issues in the practice of leadership. These objectives will be achieved through open discussion, honest self-assessment, experiential exercises, and observation of real-life leadership practice.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of theoretical and practice-based frameworks

courseDescription: Examines the basic framework of the public personnel system beginning with the legal requirements imposed by federal and state laws and regulations. General considerations of policy and procedures development, the organization of the public personnel system, the adoption of the personnel ordinance, the determination of various levels of employee status and the coverage of the personnel system are included.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of federal and state laws and regulations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of the public personnel system
Leadership in policy and procedures development

courseDescription: This course reviews the theory and application of ethics in the public sector, identifying public values and how they apply in the administration of government. It reviews sources of values employed in public sector decision-making, and reviews how values in public administration are managed and applied. Systems of professional ethics are reviewed in the context of public professions. Case studies and best practices are examined to help the student understand the application of administrative ethics in public management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with best practices in public administration
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to apply ethics in administrative decision-making
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for reviewing sources of values in decision-making
Problem-solving skills in the application of administrative ethics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership skills in managing public values
Organizational skills in applying ethics in public management

courseDescription: Analysis of human services involving direct client/agency interaction. Problems of discretion and control are examined as alternative service delivery strategies which can deal with these problems.

An overview of business-government society interactions, with special attention to the influence of public policy and corporate strategy on corporate social responsibility. An important theme is the ethical component of management decision making.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and communicating the impact of public policy on business strategy
Effective communication of corporate social responsibility initiatives
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing the influence of public policy on corporate strategy
Evaluation of corporate social responsibility measures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning in context of public policy and corporate social responsibility
Ethical leadership in management decision making

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of procurement and contract management as a core function in public sector organizations. The course introduces the student to how properly-aligned, best practice acquisitions can support public entities' strategic goals. Challenges and opportunities for all stakeholders are addressed. Special attention is given to ongoing changes in public procurement.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of procurement alignment with strategic goals
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adaptation to changes in public procurement

courseDescription: Course covers each phase of the public procurement project cycle, with an emphasis on tools and techniques to manage a public procurement project.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public procurement project cycle
Knowledge of tools and techniques for managing a public procurement project
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and management of project risks

courseTitle: Public Sector Contract Planning and Formation
courseDescription: This course provides insight into why and how public sector contracts should be planned and formed properly. A strong emphasis is placed on the strategic role that procurement can play in public sector organizations and how procurement planning and source selection, in particular, fit into that role.

courseTitle: Public Sector Procurement Law and Ethics
courseDescription: This course surveys the laws and ethics applicable to public sector procurement and contract management. A theoretical and problem-based, interdisciplinary approach is used to address the major legal and ethical issues that arise when public sector organizations plan, form, and administer contracts. Attention is given to the role of professionalization in socializing appropriate ethics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of professional ethics in procurement
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional interaction within public sector organizations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of contract formation and administration
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promotion and adherence to professional ethics

courseDescription: The course provides conceptual and practical skills in negotiations. It examines the underlying cultural, legal, and organizational issues and problems that affect managing human resources in the workplace.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of legal issues in negotiations
Knowledge of organizational issues in dispute resolution
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of cultural issues in dispute resolution

courseTitle: History of Race and Government Institutions
courseDescription: U.S. history is examined through a racial lens in the context of public administration: policies, laws, and court actions at the federal, state, and local levels. Three historical eras will be examined from colonial days to the present: Pre-Civil War Slavery, Jim Crow Segregation, and Mass Incarceration/ Colorblind Racism. Two transitional periods will also be covered: Post-Civil War Reconstruction and the Civil Rights Movement.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of public policies and laws

courseTitle: Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion: A Public Administration and Public Policy Perspective
courseDescription: Across every economic and social indicator, there are disparities that are based on race, gender, and culture. In the U.S., some of the disparities have been created by explicit and intentional discrimination that was incorporated into the U.S. Constitution and various federal, state, and local laws.  Other disparities grew out of unconscious or unintended impacts of federal, state, and local laws, policies, and practices.  This course will examine these issues within the context of public administration, developing an awareness of inequities and the skills to dismantle discriminatory policies and practices.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and discussing racial, gender, and cultural disparities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing strategies to dismantle discriminatory practices
Analyzing impacts of federal, state, and local laws and policies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promoting equity and inclusion within an organization
Awareness of organizational biases and inequities

courseDescription: This course focuses on the growing challenges and opportunities created by our interconnected world and the knowledge and abilities necessary to lead through situations in which there are misunderstandings or conflicts rooted in differences. The course explores the structure and dynamics of all forms of diversity in public, non-profit, and governmental organizations, the resulting implications for organizational health, and the critical role of cultural-competent leadership.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing dynamics of diversity in organizations
Understanding and resolving misunderstandings rooted in differences
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading through situations of cultural conflict
Promoting organizational health in diverse environments

courseDescription: This course examines the importance of social, economic, cultural, religious, and civic organizations in building or restoring communities. The course focuses on the revitalization, restoration, or upgrading of communities, cities, and localities or neighborhoods within or adjacent to cities, by the residents themselves. Viewed through the lens of social capital theory, the course further explores examples of short- and long-term change accomplished by community members on their own, within organizations, or in partnership with government officials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital tools for communication and organization
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Community problem identification and solution development
Analysis of social, economic, and cultural factors

courseDescription: This course focuses on performance-based management approaches in public and non-profit settings. It addresses the performance measurement and management process, the identification of appropriate performance measures, and the implementation of a performance measurement system, as well as managing for performance.

An examination of the fundamental concepts of collaborative governance in the field of public administration and public policy. Emphasis is placed on the government and/or nonprofit management and process of collaborative problem solving and policy implementation in cross-sector and intra-sector environments.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing collaborative processes in public administration

courseDescription: Examination of public sector financial principles, practices, and processes. A public manager's perspective of the decision making and practices of managing public funds. Introduction to governmental accounting practices. Emphasis on analyzing financial statements for decision making. Extensive use of Excel spreadsheet. Exploration of public financial management research and the link between public financial management practices and public fiscal and monetary policies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public sector financial principles
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Decision making in public fund management
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding link between public financial management practices and fiscal and monetary policies

courseDescription: This course provides students with the professional knowledge, skills, and abilities to engage successfully with local governments from the following perspectives: as a generalist public administrator, as a local government specialist, and as a citizen, non-profit leader, or businessperson. In addition, this course provides students with the theoretical and policy context within which local governments operate. Students will master that knowledge by researching how local governments use those concepts in every day administration.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with non-profit leaders and businesspersons

courseDescription: Analysis of relationship among federal, state, and local governmental units in the delivery of governmental programs. Focus on intergovernmental issues in urban metropolitan regions.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication between different government units

courseTitle: Social Marketing in the Public Sector
courseDescription: Analysis of relationships among federal, state, and local governmental units in the delivery of governmental programs. Focus on intergovernmental issues in urban metropolitan regions.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Conflict resolution within and between governmental units

courseDescription: Advanced topics in public administration.
Supervised research on a specific problem. A written report is required.

An approved research project, written under the supervision of a faculty advisor, in which the student demonstrates the capacity of design and completes independent applied research. The completed project must be approved by the dissertation committee.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with faculty advisor and dissertation committee

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Active participation in doctoral group discussions
